speaker: ABBY
text: Previously on Dance Moms...
We never discussed you forgetting your dance
and running off the stage.
When you least expect it, I'm going to throw you out there to do it.
You are representing my entire career.
The pressure is on you.
They need to get over it.
They've been jealous since Maddie from day one,
and they still are.
We wanted you to say to her,
-"why did you lie?" -Why did you lie to me?

speaker: ABBY
text: I keep telling you, it's tough getting to the top.
It's even harder to stay there.
So don't go out there and make any mistakes.
(crying) I fell and my gut hurts.
Me and Christi.
(screaming) Christi and I, you idiot!
Christi and I!
Coming up on Dance Moms...
-Done. -(bleep) you.
I told you to do it for today.
These mothers, the way they talk to you,
I think it's awful.
When those women say bad things about you, it hurts my heart.

speaker: ANNOUNCER
text: Please welcome, Paige. Thank you.

speaker: SINGER
text: âª Get up âª
âª Get on the floor âª
âª My world is with my girls living on the dance floor âª

speaker: ABBY
text: Girls, let's go! Hurry up.
Girls, you walked into this room
just as sluggish and boring
as you walked out on that stage...
zero energy.
When my girls step on stage, they're slugs.
They walk on stage.
They do the routine.
And as the two and a half minutes go on,
you can see their stamina decline.
You have to come out there with energy.
You can't get halfway through the number and then peter out.
You're boring.
So at the bottom of the pyramid, Maddie.
I don't feel that Maddie deserve to be on the bottom of the pyramid
because she rocked the group dance.
I couldn't keep my eyes off of her.
She came out with a bang, and she ended with a bang.
But you know, everybody has to have a chance
to be on the top of the pyramid.

speaker: ABBY
text: Maddie, you had an opportunity to dance.
That didn't happen.
They announced you, and you're bawling in the audience.
That is unacceptable behavior.
You're nine years old.
When opportunity knocks, open the door.

speaker: MADDIE
text: I was the very first one on the bottom of the pyramid.
And I didn't want to let her down and I think I did.
Next, Mackenzie.
Mackenzie, your routine was a winning number.
You were 10. I don't do 10.
Next, Paige.
You went out there.
You looked great. You forgot a step.
You can't forget a step.
Brooke.
Brooke, you're here because you give me this much.
I don't see this effervescent personality.
You see this fake little smile.
You're concentrating so much to not screw up the dance.
You can't have fun out there.
Next, I have Nia.
Nia, again, you're here
because you showed responsibility.
You quit fooling around.
And I didn't have to hear your mouth all day long.
Yes?
And on top of the pyramid, again, is Chloe.
Chloe, you did your solo.

speaker: SINGER
text: âª I'll keep on burning âª
But listen to me, I want more.
This week, we are going to the Energy Dance Competition
in Chicago.
So we had a great competition the last time we were in Chicago,
but we didn't win.
I'd like to win.
Nia, you and Mackenzie will be doing a duet.
Paige, you have a solo.
It's not a reward.
You can screw up your own dance by missing the choreography,
but you can't mess up other people.
Brooke, you also have a solo.
Chloe, your solo is called "Unchained."
But you know what the rule is--
you're not in class, no solo.
So we need to figure out what went on last night.
I had three faculty members come and tell me,
where's Chloe?
Why isn't Chloe in class?
She was at the doctor.
But you need to have some type of common courtesy
or at least say,
"Hey, I'm taking my kid to the doctor.
I'll bring a doctor's excuse."
I have one.

speaker: ABBY
text: Good.
Now girls, I look at this pyramid
and I don't even want to do a group dance
because you're lazy.
You're lifeless.
And you don't give me 150%.
Now this routine is about zombies
because that's what I think you are on stage.
You get out there and you're like a zombie,
you're like sleeping half the time.
Holly, you're not working anymore.
You've all the time in the world.
So you are in charge of the costumes.
For the group number?

speaker: ABBY
text: Yes.
I am not looking forward to creating the costumes
for this group number.
Costuming is not my specialty.
All right. Moms, you're dismissed.
Holly, don't procrastinate.
Everybody else spread apart.
Give me a big grand plie and wiggle your head back.
This week, the number called "Glam"
is all about zombies.
And after last week's travesty,
I really need these girls to get it together.
I need to win.
The kids are busts on a statue.
So it's like you have the long column,
and then you have their head sitting on top of it.
It's a very cool effect.
I hope the judges get it.
Make sure you hit that back attitude, Paige.

speaker: SINGER
text: âª Go, go, go, go âª

speaker: ABBY
text: Go Nia.
More, Paige.
It's not little.
It's big, Paige.
I don't think it's fair that Maddie was last in the pyramid.
I'm pissed at Abby that she told Maddie she wasn't doing a solo.
And Maddie wasn't prepared.
So Melissa, do you think that Maddie being in--
and Mackenzie being at the bottom of the pyramid is because of you?
I mean, like, my kids are always on the bottom of the pyramid
because of things I did.
(chuckles) I know.
And you know, you're not getting along with Abby
the best right now.
Do you think that's why she's at bottom of the pyramid?
No. Everything's fine.
I mean, it's never going to be what it was
because she doesn't need me anymore.
She has someone else to take care of all of her business.
I'm not working at the front desk anymore actually for Abby
because we did find someone to replace me.
And I really don't have the time.
I miss it terribly, and the people miss me.
I get emails every day from people.
But I just don't have the time.
I don't think it has anything to do with me, to be honest with you.
See, I don't agree with that.
-I really don't. -MELISSA: You don't?
The reason she's at the bottom is because you didn't kiss her ass
and do everything she wanted you to do last week.
I'm getting so much slack from everybody
that, you know, I always kiss your butt and everything.
So what's the issue?
-I don't think (indistinct) -I think you need
to confront her more.
I think Melissa has retired from her duties
at the front desk because frankly, she's made it quite clear
that she doesn't need to work anymore.
And I think that has caused a rift between her and Abby
because Abby's used to Melissa being at her beck and call.
Stand up for yourself.

speaker: ABBY
text: Stop. I gave that whole speech--
big! Big!
Paige is doing a solo this week, finally.
She is doing "Tongue Twister."
Now this is a number that she did a year ago.
And we never actually finished it
and she never did it on stage.
Face!
You have the face. Use it.
This week, my solo has a little bit of everything--
jazz, acro, gymnastics.
I like this solo a lot.
Right. Get over there in the corner.
Remember, you either make a fool out of yourself or you win.
The option is up to you.
Go.
Brooke, let's see it.
Oh, right there. Get in your feet.
Get off your heels.
Brooke has her work cut out for her this week.
This solo is tough.
Her routine is called "Paint the Picture"
because she actually makes pictures with her body.
She has one trick after another after another.
So her stamina needs to be built up.
And she has to knock one out of the park.
You're dismissed. Have your mother meet me outside, pronto.
I want to talk to you--a couple things.
-Okay. -First of all, Paige has a prop.
She has the chair.
The chair needs some rubber stoppers on the bottom of it
so that doesn't move on her on stage.
-Okay. -So I'm letting you
take that chair home tonight.
Get whatever you need done to it.
And make sure tomorrow, she has it to practice with.
The other thing I want to talk to you about
is Brooke and the voice lessons.
I want her to take from the woman that teaches here.
I don't care what you've heard. I don't care if you like her or not.
Brooke wants to sing.
And I think Brooke does have a nice voice.
But it's not about walking around singing to your iPod.
It's learning to read sheet music, learning your scales.
Get a clue, "mom-ager."
I manage her.
You signed the piece of paper that I manage her.
-Okay. -ABBY: And I want to be able to hear her.
You manage her with dance.
This is something I want to do with my daughter.
I don't want it to have anything to do with Abby.
And Abby is just so pushy.
She just wants to be in charge of everything.
Well, I don't think you know what you're doing.
Okay. If you want her to take a voice lesson here,
I will do that.
-That's fine. I just wanted (indistinct) -But that has to do with you
getting her this opportunity.
Kelly, why do you act this way? I've been telling her.
I told her 20 times in the last month--
why aren't you taking voice?
Why aren't you taking voice?
You want to do it?
All right. Then do it.
When I say sing, sing.
-Hey. -Hi.
-MELISSA: Um... -Yeah.
All the kids leave and they run to get out of here.
And my daughter, I have to drag her by the hair to leave.
-You know how that is. -ABBY: I know.
Since Maddie hasn't had a solo in two weeks,
she really hasn't had that private time with anyone
like the other girls have had.
So I just wanted her to just have a little time with Abby
and keep her skill level up.
She hasn't been dancing a lot this last week.
Can she have a private with you tomorrow
-for an hour? -An hour?
-Or whatever. -I don't know if I have an hour.
Oh, that's fine. Even half an hour, I don't care--
But you know, I have all the solo music for her.
I have costumes drawn. I have ideas.
-But she does not have the confidence. -What?
She doesn't have the fire even in the group dance.
She was much better than everybody else.
When Melissa approached me about teaching Maddie in private,
I thought, "You know what?
This is my chance to get into Maddie's head
and find out what's going on."
Yes. Absolutely.
-Okay. -Okay.
Cartwheel one.
Cartwheel two.
Woo.
I've selected the "Circus, Circus" music for Mackenzie and Nia's duet.
Run, run, dive. Go.
To one knee.
Roll.
My duet this week with Nia is an acro dance.
And I'm really excited.
And go.
One, two.

speaker: NIA
text: It's called "Circus, Circus."
I love the circus.
So Mackenzie is going to be the lion.
And Nia will be the lion tamer.
It's cute.
They'll have fun doing it.

speaker: KATHY
text: There it is. When you sing C--
(nasally) You kind of got to get it in your nose a little bit.
Abby's making me go to her voice teacher
that she has teaching at our studio.
And her name is Kathy.
You have to open your mouth no matter how horrible it looks.
-Hey, there you are. -Hello.
And where have you been, miss?
-Oh, teaching. -KATHY: Oh, well, okay.
How's she doing?
I think she can sing as well as she wants to sing.
That's nice to hear.
I've been telling Brooke 20 times in the last month--
I've said Brooke, "Take a voice lesson."
-All right. Now where's... -(indistinct) almost done.
...didn't you write a song?

speaker: KATHY
text: Let's hear it.
âª In that record round and round âª
âª Because I can't get enough of that summer sound âª

speaker: ABBY
text: Woo.
-Thank you. -We did it. You're welcome.

speaker: ABBY
text: Kelly, walk your kid 30 feet down the hallway.
Take a voice lesson once a week.
That's all I'm saying.
All right. So you have to decide.
And you tell your mother, this is what we're doing.
-Yes? -Okay.
Because I don't want any "mom-ager" ruining you.

speaker: HOLLY
text: Okay. We've got step up shop.
Woo. Full of goodies.
Abby assigned me a challenge
of creating the costumes for the group dance.
I think that Abby doesn't think I can do it.
I refuse to give her the satisfaction of seeing me fail.
Here are some images that I came up--
-Scary images. -Oh, I want my kids
to wear the toe shoes.
This week's number is all about these zombies
returning from the dead.
And they have to kind of like breathe life back into dance
because, apparently, they're so boring
when you watch them on stage, according to Abby.
-The legs. -They don't look exactly like that,
but they were the inspiration behind.
We are going to stick together as a group.
And we are going to make the costumes.
And we're going to do them fabulous.
I think once we dye it,
then we need to get some, like,
-dark, like, black, and stuff... -Darker.
...and like put around these edges.
We are ripping costumes.
We're cutting things up.
We're distressing them.
And then we just made some grass stains on them.
We spent $20 on that dress.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: Kelly is taking all of her frustrations for Abby
out on this poor little prom dress on the floor,
like, digging it into the dirt,
like, I hate you, Abby.
-Oh, look at that! -(yells)
That looks distressed.
Five, six, seven, go.
One--Chloe, you're too slow.
Energy! What are you doing? Come on!
A hot pink effin' rhinestone chair.
I've heard it before.
I should have.
I was so busy trying to get everything together
to make these costumes.
Which reminds me, you took care of your prop, right?
That's good.
It totally slipped my mind that
I had to do all this work to Paige's chair.
Oh, I was supposed to buy stoppers.
Uh...

speaker: ABBY
text: Wow. That's great energy, Brook.
Not one to make me get up and dance--boring.
Yawning.
Sloppy.
Lazy.
She's yelling at them
because their facial expressions are not expressing energy?
What does a zombie's facial expression look like?
-Exactly. Like, they're dead. -HOLLY: That's what I'm thinking, yeah.
All right. (snaps finger)
Solo. Get your chair. Let's go.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: Paige needs her chair.
-Paige needs her chair. -KELLY: Okay.
Okay. Go.
It's all done.
You're just doing it now?
Didn't you take that home last night?
I told her to take the chair.
As soon as the chair came into the room
and I touched it
and I saw that my hands were black with marker,
I knew right then and there, her mother, Kelly,
left the chair in the studio.
Dingbat.
Oh, look. She's looking to see if it's--

speaker: ABBY
text: Where are the stoppers?
I wanted these rubber stoppers.
I'll have them for the competition.

speaker: ABBY
text: No stoppers. I mean, really?
This is important, Kelly.
Do something!

speaker: ABBY
text: Done!
(bleep) you, Abby.

speaker: ABBY
text: You don't need them for the competition.
I told you to do it for today.
Now, look at that language.
Doesn't that embarrass you
that she has to use language like that?
That's a--what a truck driver uses.

speaker: MELISSA
text: Why would she do that to Paige?

speaker: CHRISTI
text: She threw the chair.
You're finished.
Next.
Who's solo?

speaker: KELLY
text: Why are you punishing Paige?
Abby should have left the room, came and spoke to me.
And I would have explained to her
why she had no stoppers on her chair--
because I was busy doing Abby Lee Miller's job,
making her costumes.
Oh.
Go get Paige.
(bleep).
You know what, Abby?
We're done.
You're not doing a solo.
Neither of my kids are doing your group dance.
-That's fine. -KELLY: Okay?
-That's fine. -Good luck making--
paying your bills without my tuition.
I pay for costumes and props.
And I don't get them.
I've been here all day making costumes for you
while you were down the road eating.
Stop eating!
That's why you're fat.
Good bye.

speaker: ABBY
text: You were a mean girl when you were 12.
You're still a mean girl.
(crying) I want to go home.
We are.
Paige was frightened because Abby is a 400-pound woman
and threw a chair with my daughter in the room.
You can credit me for the rest of my tuition for the month.
And rip up my credit card number.

speaker: KELLY
text: So I made an agreement with my girls
that I would take them to the studio.
But I was gonna stay outside with the moms and do the costumes.
I just did not want to argue with Abby.
My kids want to go in and dance.
Like, if I go in there, she's just gonna fight with me.
-You can count on that. -So can they go in with you and Nia?

speaker: HOLLY
text: I'll walk the girls in.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: I think Kelly came back because she wants
to prove to Paige and Brooke that you don't let your team down.
I'm here because my kids want to be here.
-(interposing voices) -KELLY: Paige.
What?
Don't let her upset you.
Good thing they're children and they, like,
can just forget about all this crap, because I don't know.
I have a hard time forgetting it.

speaker: MELISSA
text: Hi, honey.
Hello.

speaker: MELISSA
text: What a beautiful day.
Oh, isn't it gorgeous?
It is so nice.
-Because I'm-- -ABBY: Come on, girls. Let's go.
-MELISSA: What I think is that we need a-- -Hustle. Hustle. Hustle.

speaker: ABBY
text: Paige and Brooke come back into rehearsal.
I'm gonna let the kids do the dance.
It's fine.
We're good to go.
Let's take the whole group.

speaker: HOLLY
text: I got a lot of--
Aw, Claire and Mackenzie would have fun out here.

speaker: KELLY
text: I think it was nice for us
to actually get outside and work on the costumes
and get fresh air.
I just think it was a nice change for us.
Just because Abby's an ass,
-I wasn't going to screw the girls. -The group.

speaker: KELLY
text: Or you guys or whatever.
I'm glad you stood up to her and went.
Contestant number, blank--
Chloe with "Unchained."
Chloe's routine is called "Unchained."
It's very avant garde.
It's more of a jazz repertoire.
And again, I think this is a good number for Chloe.
Faster!

speaker: CHLOE
text: I think the style and the music,
and the personality and attitude and--
it's more like darker and mysterious.
Stomach.
It felt really good to be on the pyramid two weeks in a row.
But it's a lot of pressure.
Yes.
It's good.

speaker: HOLLY
text: Kelly, I am not only happy
to see you back and the girls back,
I'm also happy to see the costumes.
We did some great work yesterday.
We're wrapping up.
We've done just about everything we could possibly do
to these costumes.
And I'm feeling really good about them.
You're the best team ever.

speaker: KELLY
text: I feel like a zombie.

speaker: MELISSA
text: Okay. Let's hurry up and get in there.
It's really great that Maddie is going to be able to have a technique private.
Plie flex.
Feet. Feet.
See that hip up. Feet.
I know that Melissa is worried about Maddie not doing solo.
I know she cannot stand it that her kid is not the center of my attention.
I get that.
Seven, eight.
Stretch back to your shoulders.
But I am not giving in.
Maddie has to want it.
You didn't have a solo last week. You don't have a solo this week.
You need to have that fire back in you.
You love to dance, and I know that.

speaker: MELISSA
text: Of course, I started to cry, because she loves Miss Abby.
They do have this special thing.
I never had that with a teacher.
But ever since New Jersey and you exited that stage,
you're not the same Maddie.
I don't see that fire in you.
You have to show us that you want it bad.
You know--
Hey, Mom. Please don't cry.
She loves to be here.
You know that?
You know I love you?
-ABBY: I know. -And when those women
say bad things about you,
it hurts my heart.
And it hurts Maddie's heart too.

speaker: MADDIE
text: And I just walked right out of the room.
I was like, I'm embarrassed, so I need to leave.

speaker: MELISSA
text: These mothers, the way they talk to you.
I think it's awful how these kids disrespect you too.
Chloe rolls her eyes in class all the time.
-I know. I know -What I'm upset about
is that Chloe leaves class early all the time.
On Monday, she went to the doctors.
And Kelly, Christi's so-called best friend,
which they're not,
called me and said, oh, Christi is taking Chloe's out of school early today
to take her to the doctor's.
And then she's taking her to the movies.

speaker: ABBY
text: Melissa, don't worry about these three mothers
that don't know their right foot from their left.
Who cares what they think?
They're just jealous of our relationship.
And they got to get over it, like, you know.
That has nothing to do with Maddie.
I know that.
But always remember, I have her best interests.
-You always have my daughters'-- -ABBY: Where did she go?
She better be somewhere working on those feet
and not playing around.

speaker: ABBY
text: So I get on the bus and no Kelly.
Woo. Hallelujah.
Kelly can use her gas, her mileage.
She just better get there.
She better be there on time.
And those kids better be well rested.
Bus driver, where are you going?
This is not the correct way.

speaker: ABBY
text: We're going to Energy Dance in Chicago, Illinois.
You know, Chicago is the Midwest.
It's a big city.
There's lots of amazing schools that attend the competitions.
So the girls need to come out with more energy,
more enthusiasm, and more sass.
They can't be all about zombies.
Paige is on in 20 minutes.
And she's not in here. She's not ready.
And I can't find her anywhere.
-CHRISTI: Maybe she's-- -She's not backstage.

speaker: ABBY
text: Paige is on in 20 minutes.
And she's not in here. She's not ready.
And I can't find her anywhere.
She's not backstage.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: I don't know why Kelly, Brooke, and Paige aren't at the competition.
I haven't had an opportunity to talk to Kelly
because I'm busy getting Chloe ready.
So I don't really know what Kelly's mindset is at this point.
She should be in here, warming up, preparing, ready to go on.

speaker: MELISSA
text: My daughter is nine years old. She's not 18.
She doesn't make her own decisions.
And I'm gonna speak for my daughter.
So I pulled Maddie aside and had a little chat with her.
Say, "Miss Abby, I really want to do my solo today.
I want to show you how wonderful it is."
Like, you know how Paige is? How she's, like, real perky.
You can't walk out like this.
You have to go in there perky, like your perky Maddie self.
Don't go in with this face.
Remember that face, I always say I hate that face, Maddie.
Don't freak out.
Okay?
You're fine, happy.
Turn it.

speaker: MADDIE
text: My mom encouraged me to go talk to Abby
and say I was ready to do a solo.
So I'm totally confident and I'm ready to compete.
Can you please come in the hall with me?
You want me to come out in the hall and run your number?
-Yeah. -ABBY: You don't even have a number.
Maddie asked if she could talk to me.
Now, perfect example,
that's a kid taking the initiative,
asking an adult politely, "Can I speak with you?"
Sure.
I want to do my solo.
-ABBY: Are you ready? -MADDIE: Yes.
Can you beat everybody?
I think, yeah.
But you don't look-- you're like, yes.
I think, yes.
Maddie, if you don't want to do it, don't do it.
-Nobody cares. -I want to.

speaker: ABBY
text: You act like someone's making you do it.
I want to do my solo.
I think I can do my solo.
I'm ready to do my solo--very wishy-washy.
That's not a game face.
That's not the Maddie face I know,
the Maddie that's jumping and warming up,
trying to psych Chloe up.
You go out there with that face,
she's gonna beat the crap out of you.
I think you don't want to dance because you think she's gonna beat you.

speaker: MELISSA
text: She wants to dance. She's just afraid of you.

speaker: ABBY
text: Don't talk for her.
Well, I am talking. I'm her mom.

speaker: ABBY
text: Of course, without a beat,
up comes Melissa.
"Abby, she's ready. She really wants to do this."
Da da da. Da da.
I'm like, shh.
It's not about you, Melissa.
It's not your decision.
Stop with the tears.
Babies cry, not you.
-Do you understand that? -Yes.
It's my dance company.
I say who's dancing and who isn't.
So I'm looking at this kid and I thought, you know what,
throw her out there.
She needs to know if she comes to me and asks me for something,
then it means business.
And we're going through with it.
-What I'm trying to do is enter Maddie. -Okay.

speaker: ABBY
text: So I'm just letting you know that these two,
I haven't seen since we walked in the building.
-We're not gonna scratch. -Okay.
So we need to add Maddie--
I need you to enforce your rules.
So if you call them and they're not here,
and you call them again and they're not here,
-then they're an automatic scratch. -Okay.
Now I registered Maddie.
We put her in no problem.
We're good to go.

speaker: MELISSA
text: No. Because you have to run your solo. Here.
Maddie is going to do her solo.
It's--you know.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: When Melissa walks in and tells us that Maddie is now doing a solo,
I thought, well, it's par for the course.
I think Abby's greatest pleasure in life
is to put Maddie and Chloe against one another.
So this is obviously something planned.
Get out there and show her how good you are,
and that you don't need your teacher to help you.
Hello.
We are dancing.
I just didn't want to deal with Abby.
I did not want to ride on a bus with her for that long.
I haven't talked to her since we had
our argument with the chair.
I did not want to get my kids upset before they went on stage to perform.
I've been looking all over the place.
I just walked in the room two minutes ago.

speaker: ABBY
text: Better late than never.

speaker: HOLLY
text: Kelly and Abby have a very long history.
And I think with that long history,
there's a lot of tension.
I think those tensions bubble up from time to time.
It's awkward.

speaker: KELLY
text: Paige is running her solo in the Green Room,
and Abby can't even have the decency
to look up from her laptop.
With Maddie during her solo,
Paige is just nonexistent to Abby.
And Paige knows it.

speaker: KELLY
text: Why is she dancing?
Is she in our age?
Why is Maddie dancing?
Why is Maddie dancing?
-MACKENZIE: Is she actually doing it? -Yup.

speaker: KELLY
text: She was not supposed to do a solo this week.
-MELISSA: Go watch. -KELLY: Nothing against you, Maddie.
I'm just saying, they need to give my kids more time
-to rehearse theirs. -Oh, I agree.
-I agree. -It has nothing to do with you.
I am just getting more and more pissed off.
My girls were the ones that had solos this week.
Abby should have been working with them all week
instead of throwing chairs.
Somebody looks nervous.

speaker: KELLY
text: You know, it was my girls' week.
They finally got a solo.
She needed to work with them. And she didn't.
I'm done. And so are my daughters.
And I'm not letting them on that stage.
I'm pulling their solos.
Come on.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 1
text: Entry number 31A, "Tongue Twister."
Please welcome, Paige.
Thank you.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: This is entry number 31A,
Paige performing "Tongue Twister."

speaker: ABBY
text: No Paige.
I just saw her 15 minutes ago warming up in her costume.
Where is she?

speaker: ANNOUNCER 1
text: Judges, please give a hand to entry number 42A,
Brooke performing...
..."Paint the Pictures."

speaker: ABBY
text: Brooke and Paige don't show up.
Once again, Abby Lee Miller looks like the jerk.
Abby Lee Dance Company is tarnished.
Calling out their names and them not being there,
unprofessional.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 1
text: Judges, please welcome entry number 51A.
This is Chloe.
Woo!

speaker: CHRISTI
text: Woo!
As I'm watching Chloe do her solo,
I'm thinking, she is really knocking this out of the park.
She owns this stage.
This time, I just decided to stop second-guessing myself
and just go out there with confidence.
And I did.
And I thought I did really good.
So I'm going to try to do that every time.

speaker: MADDIE
text: I'm really nervous about dancing against Chloe.
But I'm more nervous for my solo,
because last time I did this solo, I forgot it.
But I need to toughen up and show Miss Abby that I can
be the same old Maddie.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 1
text: This is Maddie performing "In My Heart."

speaker: SINGER
text: âªI saw you in my dream last nightâª
âªYou had your smile so whiteâª
âªI thought your teeth were the starsâª
âªYour eyes, they were like tiny riversâª
âª Well, it gave me the shiversâª
âªWhen you looked right up at meâª
âªYou can stay here...âª

speaker: SINGER
text: âªYou can stay here...âª

speaker: ABBY
text: The CD skips.
My heart just goes... (makes sound) into my throat.
So I'm looking at that stage.
And I am like mental telepathy,
willing that kid, stay out there.
Don't move off that stage.

speaker: WOMAN
text: Go, Maddie!
-Awesome. -ABBY: Keep going! Keep going!
Keep going!
-MELISSA: Woo! -(cheers and applause)

speaker: ABBY
text: She never missed a beat.
It was a great way to come back after a catastrophe.

speaker: MELISSA
text: We did it.
My daughter is nine years old and she handled herself
like a professional on stage.
She was amazing.
I'm so proud of her.

speaker: MADDIE
text: When I walked off, I was really pleased with myself
because I just said to myself, I did it.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Here we go.
Moving on to our Energy Junior solos.

speaker: ABBY
text: I think it's a competitive thing between Maddie and Chloe.
You always need somebody to threaten you,
standing beside you pushing your buttons.
That's a good healthy competition.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Third place goes to entry number 51A,
"Unchained," Chloe from the Abby Lee Dance Company.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Second place goes to entry number 58A,
"In My Heart," Maddie from the Abby Lee Dance Company.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: Maddie might not have gotten first place at the competition.
But in Abby's eyes, she's the winner.
So what are you going to do with the group dance?
I don't know.
You know, I did not have my kids dance
because I do not want to support Abby as a dance teacher.
I didn't approve of the way Abby was treating my kids.
And I did not want them to do the group number.
But I also want my kids to know
that you can't let a group down.
I don't want it to be that my kids screwed up the group.
-HOLLY: No. -We're here to support them.
-Our kids don't care. -If you need them,
I will allow them to dance as the group.
I just want to support Kelly as a friend.
Whatever decision she makes, I want to stand behind that.
She's conflicted as a mom.
What is the right decision?
If that's your choice to have them not perform,
then we will stand by you as your friends.
They sat in that audience and watched your kids dance.
And I know all they wanted to do was go and do their dances.
So I don't want to do it to them more.

speaker: CHRISTI
text: Abby is a grudge holder.
And if Kelly pulls those kids from the group,
it's just going to perpetuate this fight longer.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 1
text: This is "Circus, Circus."
I was so proud of Nia and Mackenzie.
I can't wait until they do another duet.
They were terrific.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Nice work, ladies.
I'm very proud of Mackenzie and I,
because we pulled that duet off in three days.

speaker: KELLY
text: It's time for the last number, the group number.
And the group isn't complete without a Brooke and Paige.
So should I let the girls dance?
I think they complete the group.

speaker: MOM
text: Close your eyes.
Who's doing hair?
Woo. Looking good.
When I walked into the dressing room,
I was thoroughly impressed.
They looked like statues.
Abby, what about this for the blood?
I've never made blood before.
I think, honestly, that Abby expected me to fail.
I don't think she thought I could pull this off.
And I surprised her.

speaker: ABBY
text: Listen to me.
When you step out there,
I want you to look like somebody turned you on.
Let's give me 150% energy.
Let's suck those judges in.
And let's win.
I'm sick and tired of being top five.
Let's be on top.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Please welcome to the stage entry number 135A.
This is "Glam."

speaker: SINGER
text: âª Walk the walk Move your hips âª
âª You can talk without your lips âª
âª Movie star, head to toe âª
âª Tap your shoes, it's time to go, go, go, go, go âª
âª Steal the show, and show 'em you're the beauty queen âª
âª Get your name on the Walk of Fame âª
âª Strut âª

speaker: MELISSA
text: The girls were on stage and it is fabulous.
I think this is one of the best dances
that our girls did on stage.
The acting was great.
The makeup, the costumes, everything just came together.

speaker: SINGER
text: âª And move it to the beat âª
âª Get your swagger on and move it to the beat âª
âª Get your swagger on and move it to the beat âª
âª One, two, one, two, three âª
âª Get your swagger on âª

speaker: HOLLY
text: And I'm speechless.
The performance was excellent.
The energy was great in the group dance this week.
I don't think Abby is going to have any complaints about that.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Okay.
We are moving on to our final division,
which is our Energy division.
The top scores in our Energy division...
to top score going to entry number 75A
for "Circus, Circus," the Abby Lee Dance Company.

speaker: HOLY
text: Nia and Mackenzie
won first place for "Circus, Circus."
And I'm like, yes. They won.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: In our Energy junior small group,
we have a top three.
Third place goes to entry number 69,
"Say My Name," from Innovation.

speaker: ANNOUNCER 2
text: Our second place top score
goes to entry number 119,
"I Got You," Impact Dance Studio.
And our top scoring Energy junior small group
goes to entry number 135A, "Glam,"
Abby Lee Dance Company.

speaker: ABBY
text: The costumes, the makeup, the choreography.
It all worked together.
We are back on top.
You won first for everything.
When's the last time that happened?
Woo! We did it!
-Good job, ladies. -CHLOE: Thank you.
-Good job, Holly. -Thank you.

speaker: KELLY
text: It's at the end of the competition day
and things are winding down.
And I'm just wondering
what it is that Abby is going to say to me.
I know that she's mad at me for pulling their solos.
God only knows what's going to come out of her mouth.
Maddie and Brooke, go with Gia to get your stuff washed off.

speaker: ABBY
text: I look over at Kelly and I can tell
that brain is just tick, tick, ticking.
I mean for once, it's actually working.
She's trying to come up with some excuse,
some reason for her kids not to perform their solos.
Well, you know what?
I've had it. It's time to call her out
and let her know who's boss.

speaker: KELLY
text: I'm disappointed that my kids
didn't get to do their solos today.
But I'm glad they did the group.
I thought it turned out good.
I think they would have done fabulous.
But we'll never know.
No, we won't.
I saw them in their costumes.
They were--they were here, ready to go.

speaker: KELLY
text: Everybody else ran there's 10 times
and had an extra day of practice on it.
That's not fair.
My daughter is not going to go on stage
and forget her dance again and look like an ass
because you've made her feel flustered.
You didn't have time to run your dance?
What is this "run your dance" crap?
If you don't know by the time you get to the venue,
you're not going to know it.
What else do you want me to do?
I was ready. I was here to play ball.
I tell you to put stoppers on a chair and paint it black.
Put stoppers on the chair and paint it black.
Don't blame me and pass the buck on everybody else.
You screwed up, like you always do.
Quit enabling them.
I want kids that want to dance.
I want kids that want to be here.
And if your kid isn't one of them, cut your losses,
break your studio contract, and go.
And Kelly, I was the first one at the hospital
when your husband ran over your kid's foot.
I was in the hospital room hugging your kid.
And now you say those things about me.
How dare you?
Your kid doesn't want to dance.
They're lazy. And they don't like to lose.
